title: How do the Roman Gauls differ from the Frankish Gauls? - Quora

response.answer_text: Well, "Roman Gaul" - assuming you mean Gaul under Roman rule - describes a very wide span of time, from Caesar's initital conquest of the region to the eventual splintering and disintegration of the Western Empire. But broadly speaking, the Roman rule of Gaul saw a gradual Latinisation of the previously Celtic-speaking Gallic tribes. The Druids, who supposedly acted as the main guardians of traditional Gallic culture, customs and ritual, were hunted down and exterminated. It was under these circumstances that Gaulish was, in time, replaced entirely by Latin - though I have read some theories that Armorican Gaulish might have survived longer. Gaul was eventually conquered by the early Salian Franks in the twilight years of the Western Roman Empire. Gaul, at this point in time, was already thoroughly Latinized. For all intents and purposes, the Franks merely replaced Roman/Gothic dominion with their own. Centuries later, under the subsequent Carolingian Dynasty, the Frankish Empire would be split into three kingdoms - Western, Central and Eastern Francia. Western and Central Francia together covered most of the lands that once comprised Gaul - but the two kingdoms were ruled seperately, even if they theoretically both fell under the Frankish Empire. This would in time dissolve "Gaul" as a term of any real use or meaning. The new Frankish kingdoms of the day replaced the classical regional boundaries. The kingdom that covered most of historical Gaul was Western Francia. This kingdom was the nucleus and origin of a new country that would eventually take its name from its Frankish rulers - France. The variety of Latin spoken by the local Gallic population for so many centuries was also eventually given its own name - French. Really, there is no readily available distinction to be made between Roman Gaul and Frankish Gaul. Both periods simply represent two chapters in the formation of the French state.
